tilt.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move a part of your body, especially your head or chin, upwards or to the side
tilt.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: My mother tilted her head and smiled.
Nedâ€™s mouth tilted upwards slightly at the corners.
tilt.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move or make something move into a position where one side is higher than the other
tilt.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: As it came in to land, the plane tilted sideways.
The man was tilting his chair back.
tilt.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: if an opinion or situation tilts, or if something tilts it, it changes so that people start to prefer one person, belief, or action to others
tilt.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Crisis situations tend to tilt the balance of power in favour of the president.
Government tax policy has tilted toward industrial development.
tilt.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a movement or position in which one side of something is higher than the other
tilt.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: a slight tilt of the head
tilt.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a preference for one person, belief, or action over others
tilt.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: the recent tilt toward the Democrats
tilt.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The team is preparing for another tilt at the European Cup.
tilt.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a spoken or written attack on someone or something
